For the past two decades starting from 2004, 2D dimensional materials-based research has begun around single-layer graphene materials. As a result of a long-term effort, this interest was turned in another direction with the discovery of MXene materials in 2011. Later, this attracted tremendous attention as an excellent electrode material for the fabrication of energy storage devices due to its uncommon features of hydrophilicity and conductivity. Since it owned both pseudo-capacitive and electric double-layer behaviors, it is in high demand for the production of supercapacitors. Their inherent characteristics also lead to the promotion of electrochemical performance in batteries such as metal-ion, metal sulfur, etc. These types of apparatus were invented as a result of MXene's unique features of surface reactivity, higher density, kinetically sensitive structures, etc. Due to these advanced properties, this material is widely used in electric vehicles, sensors, catalysis, electronic devices, etc. Herein, some basic aspects of variations in MXenes, their synthesis methods, their contribution to energy storage, and their applications are discussed throughout this review article. The main focus of this review is on the energy storage mechanism of different types of MXene-based devices. It is further intended to illustrate that the flexible MXene-derived devices are also beneficial in various applications like wearable, sensing, etc. Keywords MXenes Energy storage devices Supercapacitors Batteries Flexible devices Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction 1.1 Origin of motivation With the fast-growing population around the world, the demand for the energy required for daily activities has also enhanced in the same manner. Later, the expansion of the industrial revolution led to the depletion of non-renewable energy resulting in environmental pollution, an energy crisis, and greenhouse effects. Although solar cells, hydraulic turbines, and windmills are produced green energy, the changes in the climate and limited availability of natural energy resources caused the necessity of storing energy for future purposes. As a sustainable way of overcoming this issue, many researchers experimentally discovered diverse viable candidates like supercapacitors (SCs), batteries, and fuel cells. Currently, these electrochemical energy storage devices (EESDs) play a vital role in a range of applications such as electronic apparatus, electrical or hybrid automobiles, and mobile systems [1–4]. Although batteries are rich with properties of moderate power density, high energy density, and cyclic constancy, SCs (also known as Faraday quasi, ultra, electrochemical capacitors) have high demand due to their excellent features including high capacitance, facile principle, long durability, safe operation, and high-power density. But they exhibit less energy density. Therefore, many researchers have paid attention to finding a way for improving the energy density of SCs. When considering the structure, SC consists of an anode, cathode, electrolyte, and separator. The composition of electrode material and the working potential of the electrolytes are some of the key factors which decide the electrochemical performance of the SCs. However, the cyclic steadiness, specific capacitance, and rate of the capability of the device can be improved through the modification of the morphology of the electrodes [4,5]. As electrode materials, carbon (e.g. graphene, activated carbon, nanotubes), conducting polymers (CP) (e. g. polythiophene, polypyrrole, polyaniline), and transition metal (TM) oxides, hydroxides, sulfides, phosphides, and their composites are commonly used for the fabrication of SCs. Among those, carbons are the most composing constituents in manufacturing conductors due to their copiousness, and diversity and they store electric charge via the electrostatic interactions at the interfaces of the electrodes. The arrangements of the electrode materials will not ruin the transmission of the ions even during the charge-discharge (CD) phenomena. But it helps to improve their steadiness of lifespan. Thus, the storage mechanism mainly affects changing the energy density in carbon electrodes [2,1]. Moreover, CPs have unique properties of high specific capacitance, high conductivity, and fast CD rate. Energy storage in CPs can be attained by doping and de-doping elements via redox reactions. The structure of CPs tends to expand and shrink within the CD process resulting in lower durability. Moreover, most of the CPs have relatively low power density due to their dense structures with low reacted area [3,6]. TM oxides and hydroxides show excellent specific capacitance with the high power density and stability compared with others. These materials store energy via either transferable redox reactions or the adsorption of electrons. The low conductance, operating potential, and limited activation area of those can be improved by changing the composition of the compounds [3]. 1.2 MXene-based electrode materials With the increase in demand for 2D materials for EESDs, MXene which is a common name for TM carbides, nitrides, and carbonitrides has been invented last few years ago. Especially, they are considered a member of the TM family. MXene has a unique symbolic formula of M ( n + 1 ) X n T x ( n = 1 − 4 ) in which M illustrates d-block transitional metals, X stands for C or N, and Tx indicates terminations of -O, -F, -Cl, and -OH which gives the hydrophilic ability to the surface [7,8]. The invention of the first MXene (Ti3C2Tx) in 2011, paved the way for many investigations woven around this. The thin film arrangement of this material supports the large electron movability space and it contributes to enhancing the high electric conductivity. In particular, they are more popular in the energy-related fields, because of their modifiable surface characteristics, hydrophilic reactive surface, greater mechanical strength, fast diffusion of ions and excellent conductance, etc. (Fig. 1 ) [9,10]. Hence, this can be applied as the best substitute or auxiliary for the carbons in the fabrication of electrodes. The 2D structured composition of this component plays a crucial role in the mechanism of energy storage. In there, the strong hydrogen and Van der Waals bonds between layers keep this as a multilayered nanostructure. The distances between two layers improve the rate of diffusion by providing a route for ion transportation and restricting the changes in volume in the process of CD. But it reduced the reacted surface area and redox activities. So, by introducing heteroatoms (nanoparticles, polymers, nanotubes) between films, and surface modification the interlayer space can be expanded. The best approach for that is the synthesis of MXenes with hollow spheres [7]. Herein, the gap between the sheets and the structural features of the surface are two significant factors that affect their energy storage and their property changes [11]. In EESDs, 2D- MXenes can behave as electrodes, separators, or additives [10]. In this review, we focus on discussing some of the latest innovations and technologies with their significant implications for the application of MXenes to electrochemical energy storage systems like batteries, and supercapacitors. 1.3 Scope of this review Recent studies have revealed that there are numerous possibilities for modifying the chemical and electrochemical properties of MXenes, as well as their hydrophilicity. Despite the fact that MXene is improving, there are few reports on energy storage devices that use MXene electrodes. Several articles talked about how MXenes are made, what they are like, and how they could be used to convert and store energy. But there is no static summary of the structural and functional relationships of MXene for energy storage, especially for batteries and supercapacitors, along with recent advances, which is why this review is so important in this field. This review will provide a comprehensive overview of MXenes for energy storage applications, emphasizing their chemistry, classifications, electronic and electrochemical features, and charge storage mechanisms in batteries and supercapacitors. We believe researchers working in the fields of energy conversion and storage will find this work to be of interest. 2 Chemistry, types and synthesis strategies of MXene-based materials 2.1 Fundamental chemistry It is common practice to refer to transition metal carbides and nitrides with 211, 312, and 413 crystal plans as different kinds of MAX phases, where, M, A, and X are the transition metal atoms, group-13 or 14 atoms, and functional groups (-O, -OH, -F, etc.), respectively. Several MAX phases (M2AX, M3AX2, and M4AX3) are shown in Fig. 2 a. Because M-A bonding is so prevalent in MAX phases, mechanical etching of these materials is challenging yet, which can be ascribed to the stronger M-X bonding as compared to M-A bonding [12]. Therefore, the Mn+1Xn layer can become delaminated through selective etching of A without disturbing the M-X relationship. When the layer of A-atoms is removed selectively, the transition metals in Mn+2Xn are exposed [13]. When M metals are put under stress, they undergo termination, which results in Mn+1XnTx ( Fig. 2 b) [14,15]. The surface termination composition during the etching and post-treatment process, as well as the nature of M, are all determined by the surrounding environment chemistry ( Fig. 2 c) [16] . For instance, in the Ti2AlC structure, the Ti atoms are arranged in a bilayer, with the C and Al atoms in close proximity to one other. In reality, the transition metal layers are always one more than carbon layers, and number of transition metal layers between each A-atoms layer varies across the MAX phases (211, 312, and 413). MAX was used as a starting material to create the first MXene, Ti3C2, by dissolving the Ti3AlC2 phase in HF. Using this method, numerous other MXenes were synthesized via selective etching techniques. Although MAX layers are more stable than A layers, the ideal method for creating MAX-layered networks is continuous out-diffusion [17–19]. To date, neither molten metals nor salts have been found to affect the MAX phase's exfoliation into MXene. When MAX phases were first introduced to HF, A layers were discarded while MAX multi-layers formed at the same time. MXene nanosheets' functionalities (-O, -F, and -OH), aid in the creation of semiconducting MXene. These fundamental concepts about MXenes facilitates the understanding of MXene's classification and their electronic and electrochemical properties. 2.2 Classification Based on the arrangement and compositions of the TM metals, MXenes are categorized into three groups namely, mono-transition metal oxides, double transition metal oxides, and Divacancy MXenes (Fig. 3 ). Further, each set is classified as M 2 X , M 3 X 2 , and M 4 X 3 according to the atomic structures with the number of layers [21,22]. In mono-transition metal MXenes (MTM/Mono-M MXenes), the M layers consist of a single TM type and they are called Mono-M MXenes. There are 14 Mono-M MXenes can be found even though numerous possible combinations existed. The basic structure of this material is made out of closed-packed layers, fused with an atomic layer of an A group of elements (Al, Ga, Si, Ge, P, and As). In MAX phases which have an arrangement of hexagonal structure with P63/mmc symmetry, X atoms are attached in octahedral sites. However, the bond of M-X is stronger than the M-A bonds. Therefore, it is easier to remove A elements chemically without disturbing M-X bonds. After the removal of the A group layer, M n + 1 X n can be obtained. As an outcome, the ultimate MXene ( M n + 1 X n T x ) is attained after introducing surface functional group (Tx). The second type of MXenes which is known as double transition metal (DTM) is formed with two kinds of TMs denoted by M' and M''. The main difference apart from MTM is the specific metal sites that can be occupied by these two TMs. The variations of the arrangements of those atoms in layers are shown as blue and orange colors in Fig. 4 . DTMs are synthesized only from carbides. Nitrides or carbonitrides-based DTMs were not introduced yet. By their atomic positions, these DTMs are divided into two forms, termed ordered double transition metal MXenes (O-DTM), and solid solution MXenes (SS). The defined formula for the O-DTMs is M'2M''C2 or M'2M''2C3. For instance, Mo2TiC2, Mo2Ti2C3, and Cr2TiC2 can be introduced. Mainly, those atoms (such as Mo, and Cr) controlled the electrochemical properties of the MXenes. TMs in the O-DTMs are occupied as in-plane or out-of-plane ordered structures. Within in-plane O-DTM which has the formula of M'4/3M2''X2/3XTx, two different TMs are arranged in each M-layer with alternating spots (Fig. 5 a). Thus, those metals are distributed in out-of-planar O-DTM as separate layers, where inner layers and outer layers are filled with only M' and M'' TMOs respectively (Fig. 5 b). The unique formula for outer-plane order structure is M'2M''X2Tx or M'2M2''X3Tx. In contrary to ordered MXenes, the metals in SS ones are arbitrarily spread throughout the M layers (Fig. 5 c). Mainly, ( Ti , V ) 2 C T x , ( Ti , Nb ) 3 C 2 T x , and ( Nb , Zr ) 4 C 3 T x are considered as examples for SS MXenes indicating the general formula of (M', M'')n+1CnTx. The structural changes in M layers lead to the control of the optical, mechanical, magnetic, and electrochemical properties of these substances [22]. As the third type, divacancy MXenes are designed from the parent 3D atomic structure (MAX phase). Here, some approaches of in-plane chemical etching and selective etching have been applied to produce them with ordered divacancies. Transformation of 2D - M o 1.33 C from the ( M o 2 / 3 S c 1 / 3 ) 2 A l C by selectively removing the Al and Sc can be considered as an example of this synthesis. With regard to past records, divacancy MXenes is one of the best 2D materials showing the highest conductivity and the highest specific capacity. The introduction of the divacancies can be applied as a method of reducing the mass density of materials [23]. 2.3 Synthesis strategies 2.3.1 Top-Down approach Although different methods can be used to produce MXenes, the top-down and bottom-up methods are two specific approaches. Of these, top-down methods which are carried out in the liquid base medium are more popular. In that sense, the basic mechanism of the top-down process is based on a chemical-mechanical strategy in which ‘A’ elements are removed from the MAX phase using a proper liquid solution. MAX is a tertiary carbide or carbonitride formed as a closely packed atomic layer. Typically, the bond between metal and A is strong. But binding with hydroxyl, oxygen, and fluorine groups can make the bond weaker due to the reactivity of the etchants. Here, HF-containing (e.g.: aqueous HF) or non-HF-containing solvents like HCl, and NH4HF2 are used as etchants for the activation. This top-down synthesis method can be classified in several ways such as Hydrogen Fluoride (HF) etching, Fluoride salt etching, NH4HF2 etching, alkali treatment, and molten salt etching. HF Etching: In 2011, Gogotsi and his group invented T i 3 C 2 T x by removing Al from the parent MAX phases (Ti3AlC2) using selective HF treatments as an initial step of this innovation [24,25]. For example, the synthesis reactions of MXenes via the HF etching process are as follows, (1) T i 3 Al C 2 ( s ) + 3 H F ( aq ) → Al F 3 ( aq ) + T i 3 C 2 ( s ) + 1.5 H 2 ( g ) (2) T i 3 C 2 ( s ) + 2 H F ( aq ) → T i 3 C 2 F 2 ( s ) + H 2 ( g ) (3) T i 3 C 2 ( s ) + 2 H 2 O ( aq ) → T i 3 C 2 ( OH ) 2 ( s ) + H 2 ( g ) This process is initialized with the addition of Ti3AlC2 MAX powder into hydrogen fluoride solution at room temperature. This reaction is exothermic Eq. (1)). So, it is necessary to add MAX powder gradually to avoid excessive bubble formation. The etching step provides a 2D-multi-layered structure in the MXenes bond with the hydrogen and van der Waals bonds. Consequently, the residue should be washed with deionized water to remove the reacted products (AlF3), and sedimentary acids. After several repeated pieces of washing through centrifugation, the produced MXenes are collected by vacuum filtration when pH reaches ∼ 6. Furthermore, the final product can be customized by applying post-processing techniques. After treatment with an etchant solution rich in fluoride and hydroxyl ions, the surface of the T i 3 C 2 nanofilms are ending up with certain active polar groups (O, OH, and F) that provide hydrophilicity (Eqs. (2), (3) [10]. This HF etching can be applied for the synthesis of Ti, V, Ta, Cr, Mo, Nb, and Zr-based MXenes. Primarily, the fluoride ion attack is more efficient at removing the basic element than the acidic ones at the MAX stage. The etching process can be improved by changing the properties of etchants such as their concentration, composition, processing time, and temperature. Some studies have found that the concentration and duration of the HF etching can be improved with the increase of the “M” atomic number. This happens because of the enhancement of the bond strength between M and A. Even though a multi-layered structure is obtained via this acid etching, a mono-layer or few-layered nanosheets can be produced through delamination, carried out by sonication with organic intercalator-like isopropanol, tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), etc. In addition, these organic molecules can be replaced by various metal ions (Li+, Na+, K+), algae extract, and hydrazine monohydrate [26,27]. Fluoride Salt Etching: Although HF acts as an effective etchant, its properties of extreme toxicity and excessive corrosiveness due to its high acidity led to finding alternative ones. As a result of strenuous effort, it has been introduced in-situ HF-forming (also known as fluoride salt etching) methods that involved fluoride containing the acidic solution to form HF indirectly for getting rid of Al elements. LiF /HCl mixture, NH4F, ammonium hydrogen fluoride (NH4HF2), NaHF2, and KHF2 etching are some examples of this category. As a great leap forward in this field, Ghidiu and his team in 2014 has been discovered a safer route to remove metal (Al) and to the synthesize of a 2D carbide layer by reacting with fluoride salts (LiF) and hydrochloric acid (HCl) [28]. This innovation paves the way to modify the Ti3AlC2 very easily. This process was started by mixing LiF and HCl (Eq. (4)), followed by adding MAX powder slowly. During the etching step, it was heated at 40 °C for 45 hrs. The by-products (LiCl, AlF3) were removed by washing. Next, water addition, centrifugation, and decanting processes were performed to increase the pH as the previous method. The final clay-type paste was rolled within the roller mill to obtain a flexible film of MXenes. (4) Li F ( aq ) + HC l ( aq ) → H F ( aq ) + LiC l ( aq ) This method is applicable not only for LiF but also for other fluoride salts such as NaF, KF, CsF, CaF2, and tetrabutylammonium fluoride in HCl for MXene synthesis. The specific feature is that above all compounds show the same pattern in etching. The main factors influencing the improvement of this etching process are the strength of the intermolecular bonds, the size of the molecules, and the MXene design [9]. Moreover, this LiF and HCl mixture can etch other MAX phases such as Nb2AlC and Ti2AlC. The stoichiometric ratio of the LiF to HCl affects the changes in the lateral size of the nanosheets, quality, and producibility of the outcome. It is experimentally found that MXenes flakes with high, clear surface area exhibit higher electrical conductivity due to their low defects on sheets. And also, the lateral sizes and density of the defects are mainly depending on the fraction of LiF in the reaction and the sonication action. Furthermore, Ghidiu and his group tried to use H2SO4 instead of HCl. Although MXenes were gained, they noted that this should be studied in more depth [28]. Chuanfang et al. discovered that high-quality MXenes could be produced by combining common acids such as HCl and H2SO4 with LiF [10]. The formation of fluoride from these types of reactions enhances the space between layers in the MXenes. This happened due to the interconnection of positively charged ions (Li+, Na+, K+, etc.) and F − ions. This is the main advantage of this method. Typically, this result cannot be obtained by using HF alone. The area between layers in these MXenes is higher compared to HF etching. Therefore, it allows transferring ions at higher speed rates and supplies more places for reactive ions. As another benefit, this method can lower the defects while HF etching has more destructions [10]. The main disadvantages when compared with HF are, that a lower concentration of hydrogen fluoride and F − salts are needed to carry out this process. For this reason, it takes a longer etching time resulting in poor etching effects. It is difficult to get accordion-like morphology using this approach [11]. NH4HF2 Etching: In the same year (2014), Halim and his collaborators discovered another effective secure path for producing MXenes using NH4HF2. [29]. The importance here is that this is a milder etchant and it has less toxicity compared to HF. As discussed earlier, the same procedure as above is carried out for this etching also. But the difference is only used the etchant type. Unlike HF etching, this results in the formation of byproduct [ ( N H 4 ) 3 A l F 6 ( a q ) ] as removal of Al elements (Eq. (6)). During the etching process, ammonium ions of NH3, NH4 +species, and their hydrates are bound in between the Ti3C2Tx layers simultaneously as others (Eq. (7)). Compared with HF-treated MXenes, the final product of this process appeared as thicker MXene films with larger inter-layer areas due to the variations in intercalation ions. (6) T i 3 Al C 2 ( s ) + 3 N H 4 H F 2 ( aq ) → T i 3 C 2 ( s ) + ( N H 4 ) 3 Al F 6 ( aq ) + 1.5 H 2 ( g ) (7) T i 3 C 2 ( s ) + aN H 4 H F 2 ( aq ) + b H 2 O ( aq ) → ( N H 3 ) c ( N H 4 ) d T i 3 C 2 ( OH ) x F y ( s ) + z H 2 ( g ) Overall, etching via fluorine-rich compounds always provides a high yield of MXene materials. Thus, the size of the product and interlayer space can be controlled by regulating the etching duration, the quantity of the etchants, and the used post-treatments. However, with the reaction between outermost TMOs and etchants during the etching period, some defects in the surface layer occur due to the formation of a chaotic film of functional groups. Also, introducing fluorine groups to the MXene layer brings some difficulties in energy storage. Therefore, this is a major reason to develop a better way to fabricate MXene to use in supercapacitors [30]. Alkali Treatment: In 2018, Zhang and his team discovered another fluorine-free approach for the synthesis of MXenes using strong alkaline compounds [31]. Due to the strong binding ability of Alkali with the basic elements, it is highly effective as an etching agent in the removal of Al from the Ti3AlC2. In this case, OH− ions are attacked in two steps onto Al layers in Ti3AlC2. First, Al is oxidized into its hydroxide form which, then dissolves in sodium hydroxide as soluble Al (OH)4 −. However, there is a drawback with this process being able to form some oxides or hydroxides on top of the Ti3AlC2. The HF water solution should be further treated to remove those. As the best solution for that, this research group suggested that the acceptance of the Bayer process which was established by K. J. Bayer in 1887 can be applied. It has been shown that this etching under high temperatures and higher alkali concentrations helps to liquefy easily the by-products which block the Al layer removal. Here, this team experimentally proved that 92 wt.% purity of Ti3C2Tx MXenes can be fabricated by treating them with 27.5 M NaOH at 270 °C [31]. Molten Salt Etching: In 2016, Urbankowski et al. found the first 2D transitional metal nitride (Ti4N3) based MXene [32]. Although earlier discussed MXene production methods occurred in the aqueous medium, where the etching of Al element from Ti4AlN3 powder using molten fluoride salt occurs at 550 °C under an argon flow. Much research has found a way of producing carbide and carbonitride. But the nitride-based MXenes are difficult to produce because of two reasons. The first factor is the cohesive energy of the T i n + 1 N n is lower than that of T i n + 1 C n and this is reversely true for the formation energies. The less cohesive energy leads to the lower stability of the structure of T i n + 1 N n . High formation energy means this need more energy for the extraction of Al atom from T i n + 1 A l N n because the bond between metal and nitride group stronger than in carbides. Another reason is the lower stability of T i n + 1 N n leads to high dissolution in HF solution. Therefore, this makes trouble while doing the etching process. However, the electrochemical performance is higher in TM nitrides than in carbides. So, this is a suitable candidate for the fabrication of electrodes in ESDs. Later in 2019, Huang et al. experimented with the same method for the synthesis of MXenes from Ti3ZnC2 using zinc chloride (ZnCl2) as an etchant [33]. In the molten state, the TM halides behave as a Lewis acid which can accept electrons. Initially, ZnCl2 was ionized into Zn2+ and ZnCl4 2− as molten states at the melting point of 280 °C. In that sense, ionic Zn+2 plays the role of electron acceptor. In this acidic condition, the Al atom which was weakly fused in the MAX phase oxidized into Al3+via redox reaction, and then it reacted with Cl− ions to form AlCl3 at 550 °C (Eq. (8)). The formed AlC3 was rapidly evaporated because of its low boiling point of 180 , , ,°C. Meantime, the reduced form of Zn was moved to the vacant site in place of the Al atom resulting in the synthesis of the final product of MXene (Eq. (9)). In general, these above two reactions can be written as one equation for the process of molten salt etching (Eq. (10)). (8) T i 3 Al C 2 ( s ) + 1.5 ZnC l 2 ( aq ) → T i 3 C 2 ( s ) + 1.5 Z n ( s ) + AlC l 3 ( g ) (9) T i 3 C 2 ( s ) + Z n ( s ) → T i 3 Zn C 2 ( s ) (10) T i 3 Al C 2 ( s ) + 1.5 ZnC l 2 ( aq ) → T i 3 Zn C 2 ( s ) + 0.5 Z n ( s ) + AlC l 3 ( g ) To similar the synthesis of T i 3 Zn C 2 , novel MXenes such as T i 2 ZnC , T i 2 ZnN , V 2 Z n C are fabricated via this method. Furthermore, Cl-terminated MXenes can be produced by further etching with ZnC l 2 molten salt. For instances, T i 3 C 2 C l 2 , T i 2 CC l 2 synthesized from T i 3 Zn C 2 , T i 2 ZnC . But, T i 3 NC l 2 , and V 2 CC l 2 cannot be obtained because the bond strength between Metal and A in T i 2 ZnN , V 2 Z n C are relatively high. Some reports specified that Cl-terminated MXenes exhibit higher stability, and improved electrochemical behavior than other halide-terminated ones [33]. In 2020, Talapin et al. further studied this field and they developed this method by using chromium chloride or chromium bromides instead of ZnCl2 [34]. Electrochemical Etching: While the aforementioned etching procedures have been used to create different MXenes, the use of an etchant can sometimes have unintended consequences. Therefore, etchant-free etching techniques like electrochemical etching can reduce the possibility of negative impacts caused by etchants. The chemical activity of the M-A bond is crucial to the electrochemical etching process [35], as it is involved in the electron transfer that is part of the surface reaction. Ion intercalation weakens the Van der Waals connections between layers, which is why electrochemical techniques can produce monolayer 2D flakes [36]. To conduct the electrochemical etching experiment, a working electrode (MAX material) and a counter electrode were dipped in electrolyte, and when a potential is applied, ions form, expanding the MAX phase into 2D nanosheets [37]. When subjected to either cathodic or anodic potentials, the MAX layers can expand, detach, and exfoliate [38]. By performing cathodic exfoliation in a non-aqueous environment, two-dimensional materials can be protected against oxidation, and high-quality, non-oxidized nanoplates can be produced. BP flakes form often in ambient settings due to the cathodic intercalation of tetra-alkylammonium cations. Using an aqueous electrolyte and an anode, Yang et al . [36] demonstrated an F-free etching process based on Ti3AlC2 (Fig. 6 (a-i)). This etching was done in a tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMA-OH) and NH4Cl alkaline solution. Ti3AlC2 was used for the anode, but the Cl− in the electrolyte quickly corroded the Al and broke the Ti-Al bond. After the subsequent incorporation of NH4OH into the nanosheets, the anode Ti3AlC2 was rapidly etched to completion and spurred further etching beneath the surface. 2.3.2 Bottom-Up approach The synthesis of MXenes via the bottom-up approach consists of two steps. First, the thin film of MAX develops by the deposition on the new crystal layer with well-defined orientations. Subsequently, MXenes are produced by the etching of A layers. Through these routes, transparent conductive MXene layers on the clear crystal substrate can be obtained. There are two ways of using bottom-up methods. In 2014, Halim et al. discovered sputtering deposition of MAX thin films over sapphire support to fabricate Ti3C2Tx [29]. As mentioned earlier, the Ti3AlC2 thin films have been dropped to the sapphire substrate using magnetron sputtering of Ti, Al, and C tubes. To increase the adhesiveness of the substrate, a smooth TiC incubation layer was applied. After deposition, both the MAX phase and sapphire were immersed into etching agents (aqueous HF or NH4HF2) resulting in Ti3C2Tx. Herein, the TiC incubation layer produced gaseous vacuum deposition methods, for example, chemical vapor deposition (CVD), and atomic layer deposition (ALD). This delivers clear evidence that monolayer MXene nanosheets can be synthesized via this technique. As another bottom-up method, the thermal deposition of Mo2C thin films over metallic or non-metallic supports can be considered. There is no sufficient proof for the synthesis of those MXenes directly. But Mo2CTx can be introduced as one of the examples of the formation of an epitaxial thin film from the MAX phase of Mo2GaC. In that sense, two layers of Ga are assembled in between Mo2C layers which can be formed via CVD. And also, α- Mo2C can be successfully produced within the mixture of hydrogen and methane gases under high temperatures. However, Mo2CTx is produced with the elimination of Ga elements via selective HF etching. Further, this technique was applied to manufacture Mo-contained binary-metal MXenes like Mo2TiC2Tx and Mo2Ti2C3Tx. Overall, those two procedures are mainly functionalized for the direct synthesis of the crystal form of MXenes [39–42]. The growth of the MXene synthesis can be summarized as follows in Fig. 7 . 2.3.3 Delamination of MXenes via intercalating species Multilayer MXenes are created when the A layer of the precursor MAX material is selectively etched. Separate 2D layers can be obtained much more quickly and easily with the help of a wide variety of intercalating species. The accordion-like structure created following the etching of the MAX precursor exhibits an increase in the spacing between the layers as a result of their intercalation. This greatly reduces the strength of the interlayer contacts in multilayer MXenes, making mechanical exfoliation much easier [43]. Fig. 8 a is a schematic depiction of an intercalant-mediated top-down synthesis of MXene [44]. The process of isolating MXenes via intercalation is greatly accelerated by this method. The MXene multilayer solution is mixed after the intercalant is added, rinsed and centrifuged to remove the exfoliated material, and finally allowed to reach a pH of 7 in the supernatant. Sonication is often used as a secondary process after mixing. However, the planar dimensions of the MXene are reduced and the number of defects is increased due to prolonged sonication at high power [43]. Intercalants can be used to create single-layer MXenes with improved resistance to aggregation and adhesion [45] Organic solvents and metal cations are both examples of intercalants [46]. Organic intercalants include TBAOH, tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH), n-butylamine, and choline hydroxide [46]. Hydrazine monohydrate dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was utilized for intercalation in a study by Mashtalir et al. [44]. As can be seen in Fig. 8 (b-c), MXene remains delaminated after intercalation, and multilayers thicken, presumably as a result of the gluing together of distinct monolayers to produce lamellae. Single MXene nanolayers were obtained in two dimensions after sonication and centrifugation. Sonication is needed to keep the multilayer carbides from settling to the bottom of the DMSO solution when distributing MXene sheets. In this situation, the diameters of DMSO-exfoliated nanolayers are typically on the range of several hundred nm [47]. TBAOH and TMAOH, both tetraalkylammonium compounds, are effective intercalants [48,49]. In contrast to DMSO, which relies on ultrasonic treatment, TBAOH and TMAOH are based on ion exchange between protons and bulk tetraalkylammonium ions, TMA+ or TBA+, causing the MXene layers to "swell" and lead to delamination even with manual shaking. Even after annealing at temperatures exceeding 750 °C, the electrical characteristics of MXene (increased sample resistance and negative dR/dT) were found to benefit from TBA+ intercalation. These findings are useful for optimizing MXene systems, where metallic conductivity is essential, and where sensors can benefit from the controllable dR/dT afforded by intercalation [48]. In aqueous solutions, metal ions serve as intercalants, and examples include halide salts and metal hydroxides. The negative charge of MXenes makes it possible for a wide variety of metal cations, including NH4 +, Mg2+, Al3+, Ca2+, Li+, Na+, K+, and Sn4+, to intercalate spontaneously [50]. By increasing the separation between nanolayers after intercalating, these ions undermine the Van der Waals force that is essential to the formation of MXene's layered structure. A rise in pH and gradual expansion of the multilayer MXene follow repeated washings of the slurry in deionized water. Then, by shaking or sonicating, you can get monolayer carbides in two dimensions [10]. Using MXene with intercalated K+ cations for the NF electrode has been shown to boost the specific capacity by more than two times compared to ordinary MXene and to provide significantly higher efficiency of ion and electron transport [51]. Li+ cations in Ti3C2Tx were similarly discovered to significantly boost MXene's electrical conductivity [52]. Two-dimensional carbides undergo Li+ intercalation, and water molecules spontaneously intercalate between the layers. Other cations, such as Na+, K+, Ca2+, and Mg2+, intercalated with Ti3C2Tx to beneficial effect as well. They altered the framework's reaction to moisture and humidity [53]. 3 Electronic and electrochemical properties of MXene-based materials Due to unique surface structure and functionalities, MXenes offers an extraordinary collection of electronic, mechanical and electrochemical properties. MXenes are distinctive from other 2D materials like graphene due to their hydrophilic properties and enhanced thermal conductivities. The related characteristics and charge storage performances of MXene-based materials can be adjusted by varying their geometric structure, morphology, surface functioning, and composition. The next subsection discusses the electronical and electrochemical properties, as well as how they relate to charge storage performance [54–56]. 3.1 Electronic features One of the most crucial features of MXene is its electrical characteristics. MXenes' surface groups (-OH, -F, -O) are amenable to modification by manipulation of synthetic route and reaction conditions [57]. For instance, as more 4-nitrophenyl groups were grafted onto the surface of MXene using 4-nitrobenzene-diazonium tetrafluoroborate salts, the conductivity and mobility of single-layer Ti3C2Tx MXene dropped (Fig. 9 (a-c)) [58]. By changing the surface groups of MXenes by substitution and elimination processes in the molten inorganic salt, it is possible to modify the electrical properties of MXenes, such as their work function, conductivity, and mobility [59]. In addition to the aforementioned factors, the MXenes synthesis method itself has an impact on the materials' electrical properties. In many cases, MXene with higher conductivity can be synthesized by using gentler etching conditions. This is due to the fact that MXene's structure can be efficiently preserved with only a small amount of etching, and the resulting nanosheets are large and nearly defect-free. MXenes' high conductivity stems from the combination of their internal metal layer's efficient electron transport properties and the high density of electrons around the Fermi level induced by the d-orbital electrons of the transition metal layer [60,61]. The electrical properties of MXenes are also significantly affected by changes in their surface groups and transition metal layer. In M3C2 and M4C3 MXenes, for instance, the outer transition metal layer can be modified by replacing Ti with Mo to alter the material's behavior in terms of electron transport from a metal to a semiconductor. As shown in Fig. 10 a, the resistivity of Mo-containing MXene is greater than that of the comparable Ti-containing MXene at all temperatures tested. Contrary to Mo-containing MXenes with surface groups -OH or -F, the Mo-containing MXene with the surface group -O displayed the metal electron transport behavior [62]. In addition, the pressed MXene films had electrical conductivities that matched those of multilayer graphene and exceeded those of nanocarbon tubes. It was clear that functional molecules could impede resistivity increase by adding new layers. This causes the conductivities of the simulated functions to be much higher than what is seen in experiments [63]. Differences in surface functionality, defect concentration, d-spacing between MXenes particles, delamination yield, and lateral dimensions brought about by the etching method all contributed to the wide range of electrical conductivities observed for Ti3C2Tx, which ranged from 850 to 9870 S/m [64]. MXenes with higher electrical conductivity and fewer imperfections are typically the result of increased lateral expansion paired with shorter etching durations [65]. They may also have electrical conductivities that are affected by moisture in the surroundings, making them attractive for use in sensing applications [66]. 3.2 Electrochemical features It is possible to moderately oxidize MXene, with MXene functioning as a reducing agent and noble metal ions functioning as oxidants, to change the oxidation state of the M element, which is typically strongly influenced by the nature of the terminating group [67]. The high electrochemical characteristics of MXenes and Ti3C2Tx MXenes in particular can be attributed to the abundance of redox sites in these materials. Ti's ever-changing oxidation state is caused by the hydronation of the oxygen-terminated group. When the potential is altered, the oxidation state of Ti almost immediately follows suit [68,69]. Depending on the electrolyte's cation size, surface terminations, morphology, inter-layer spacing, etc., Ti3C2Tx exhibits a wide range of capacitance characteristics. Ti3C2Tx interlayers generate electrostatic repulsion when electrolytic cations intercalate between them. As the interlayer spacing is lower than the cation size, the cations will intercalate through the interlayers [70,71]. The fast-redox reaction will cause pseudo capacitance effects. Yet, large cations are unable to diffuse across the interlayers and instead reject each other electrostatically, ensuring the integrity of the cycle. A double-layer capacitance is generated by adsorption of cations at the surface [72]. This explains why MXene's storage capacity in acids is so impressive. To illustrate the electrochemical reaction, consider the following (Eq. (11)) [73]. (11) T i 3 C 2 O x ( OH ) y F z + δ H + + δ e − ↔ T i 3 C 2 O x − δ ( OH ) y + δ F z The T i 3 C 2 O x − δ ( O H ) y + δ F z MXene generated by the in-situ HF method showed its highest theoretical capacity of 615 C/g, whereas the experimental capability of MXenes has only been reported to be around 135 C/g. As a result of such hypothesis, it has been found that the electrochemical properties of MXene anodes are primarily affected by the preparation factors, functional groups, thermal treatments, and chemical oxidation, all of which are highly interconnected. The electrochemical behavior of the vacancy-containing material i-MXene (Mo1.33CTz) was studied by El-Ghazaly et al., [74] in sulfate-based aqueous electrolytes containing univalent (Li+, Na+, or K+) or divalent (Mg2+, Mn2+, or Zn2+) cations (Fig. 8a). The results show that the Mo1.33CTz MXene electrodes were stable in the sulfate electrolytes over a potential window of more than 1 V of operation. When tested in a 1.0 M MnSO4 solution, the Mo1.33CTz MXene electrodes showed a volumetric capacitance of up to 677 F/cm3. Despite being subjected to 5000 charge/discharge cycles, the asymmetric devices retained 97% of their original capacitance. Fig. 10 (b-g) shows the analysis's findings, where, the intercalating cations may be used to enhance the electrochemical performance of Mo1.33CTz MXene. Further, Li et al. [75] studied the charge storage mechanism of a Ti3C2Tx-based-Zn ion hybrid micro-SC with Zn as the anode and Ti3C2Tx as the cathode. In order to develop the highly efficient electrochemical SC, researchers found that Zn transformed into Zn2+ during the discharge process and was transferred from the anode to the Ti3C2Tx MXene cathode, intercalating the layers of MXene. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis indicated the intercalation of Zn2+ ions into MXene layers, as well as the distribution of Ti, C, and Zn components in the cathode [75]. The electrochemical performance of MXene-based supercapacitors is highly dependent on a number of factors, including the synthesis method, MXene precursor, MXene dimension and architecture, electrolyte, electrode architecture, and the amount of MXene dispersed as a filler in a given composite. 4 MXene-based electrodes for batteries and supercapacitors 4.1 MXene-based materials for batteries Like supercapacitors, batteries also have attained vast attraction as clean energy storage devices. Due to their versatile properties of longer life cycles and higher energy densities, they are the most commonly used power source for basic needs to large-scale industrial applications. The battery also consists of two electrodes (anode, cathode), a separator, and electrolytes (Fig. 11 ). The negatively charged electrode (anode) can oxidize by producing electrons. Through the consumption of electrons, the cathode might be reduced. In a fully charged state, an anode is rich in electrons and a cathode is not. Redox reactions are taken place in charged electrodes to power the battery. Here, oxidation happens to anions at the anode while the positive electrode is responsible for occurring reduction reactions of cations. Both electrodes are connected electrically through the electrolytes. In the charging process, when a current is supplied to the cell, the anode changes to the cathode and vice versa. At this time, the oxidation states of the materials are exchanged and they are returned to their initial state, ready to be discharged. During discharging, electrons move from the anode to the cathode via an external circuit by producing current. This occurs because ions transfer through the electrolyte. The electrical potential difference between those electrodes is electromotive force (EMF) which indicates the ability of the cell to conduct an electric current from the inside to the outside. Once the cathode and an anode are reduced and oxidized respectively, there is no use for battery anymore. Then, it might be ending in the life cycle of the battery cell. As a result of novel advancements in the research related to the EESDs, metal-ion, metal-sulfur, and metal-air (metal stands for Li, Na, or K) batteries are invented as rechargeable, portable, efficient devices for any type of energy-required applications. Here, the structure, charge storage mechanism, and application of MXenes in each battery are briefly discussed in the next section. 4.1.1 Metal-Ion batteries Mxenes have acted as anode materials for metal ions (lithium-ion/ sodium-ion), and solid-state batteries, resulting from their morphological characteristics of high inter-sheet spacing and layered structure. Among metal-ion batteries, Li-ion batteries (LIBs) have a high performance by showing high power density, moderate energy density (200 Wh/ kg), and low self-discharge compared with others. Normally, un-delaminated MXenes provide more spaces at each transitional metal ion to attach to other molecules which helps to improve their properties. Therefore, there is a chance to enhance capacitance through the modification of the surface in MXenes [77]. Most of the research has been studied related to the LIBs which are made from 2D MXenes, especially TM carbides like Sc2C, Ti2C, Ti3C2, V2C, Cr2C, and Nb2C. They have further concluded that the functional groups on the surface mainly affect the Li-ion storage and the highest capacitance in LIBs exhibited from the oxygen-terminated MXenes. In this section, some achievements of MXenes in metal ion batteries are further discussed. Commonly, titanium-based MXenes are used as electrodes for LIBs due to their unique characteristics of eco-friendliness, high capacitance, low expense, and high availability. In 2012, Tang and his group examined the Ti3C2-derived MXenes (Ti3C2(OH)2 and Ti2C2F2) to determine the properties of mono-Ti3C2 with hydroxylated and fluorinated surfaces. When comparing results, the sequence of the Li-ion diffusion rate was changed as T i 3 C 2 > T i 3 C 2 F 2 > T i 3 C 2 ( O H ) 2 . With the presence of OH and F on the surface, those groups hinder the Li-ion transfer within the system resulting in lower conductivity. It was ensured that Ti3C2 has high storage volume and a low blockage to transfer Li-ions which is suitable as an anode material for LIBs [78]. Later, Mashtalir et al. examined the possibilities of preparing Li-ion batteries using Ti2C and Ti3C2 as anode for LIB [44]. With the analysis of the data, they finally concluded that the gravimetric capacity of Ti3C2 is 50% lower than that of Ti2C. And also, they further confirmed that Ti2CTx has 1.5 times greater gravimetric capacitance compared with Ti3C2Tx. Most of the research regarding the synthesis of EESDs using MXenes was carried out based on titanium carbides. For the first time, novel 2D vanadium and niobium carbide-based LIBs were discovered by Naguib's group as a great innovation. Those electrode materials (V2CTx, Nb2CTx) were synthesized through the process of selective etching of Al from V2AlC, and Nb2AlC, respectively. When considering the chemical performances of both electrodes in LIBs, V2CTx showed a lower reversible capacity of 260 mAh/g, while Nb2CTx was obtained at 288 mAh/g at the same cycling rate of 1C over 50 cycles. However, those data are higher in values compared with previously discussed titanium carbides. V2CTx and Nb2CTx-based LIBs have capable of showing great performances at higher cycling rates, proving reversible conductance of 125 mAh/g and 110 mAh/g after 150cycles at 10C for Nb2CTx, and V2CTx respectively. These results evidenced that these electrode materials have a high potential window and have rapid Li diffusion within the layers of MXenes. Therefore, those type of LIBs is very effective for high-power applications such as electric vehicles, portable electronics, and aerospace apparatus [77,79]. 4.1.2 Metal-Sulphur batteries The characteristic of high specific energy brings popularity to metal sulfur batteries in the field of energy storage. Among them, lithium-sulfur battery (LSB) is considered the best alternative EESD because of its environmental friendliness and non-toxicity. Due to the low atomic weight electrode materials (Li and S), those are light in weight. Herein, the specific capacity of the anode shows 3860 mAh/g while the cathode has 1675 mAh/g. It was statically calculated that the specific energy of this battery can be achieved at 2500 Wh/kg while Li-ion achieved a fairly lower value than this. The CD process occurs as conversion-type reactions within this system. During the charging, Li ions and electrons are released from the negative electrode Eq. (12)). Then, these Li+ ions are traveled to the cathode through the electrolyte. Meanwhile, the positive electrode becomes rich with electrons (e −) result of the external charge supply. In the discharging processes, S8 is reduced to long-chain lithium poly-sulfides form ( L i 2 S n , n ≥ 4 )as below (Eqs. (13)-(17)). The reaction of L i 2 S 4 further, it gives the short-chain of L i 2 S n ( n = 1 , 2 ) as in Eqs. (16) and (17). (12) Li → L i + + e (13) 2 L i + + S 8 + 2 e − → L i 2 S 8 (14) 2 L i + + 3 L i 2 S 8 + 2 e − → 4 L i 2 S 6 (15) 2 L i + + L i 2 S 8 + 2 e − → 2 L i 2 S 4 (16) 2 L i + + L i 2 S 4 + 2 e − → 2 L i 2 S 2 (17) 2 L i + + L i 2 S 2 + 2 e − → 2 L i 2 S Although this battery is beneficial for different applications, some drawbacks are related to the sulfur (S) cathodes. The density of the S element is relatively high and it leads to expanding the volume by about 80% within the CD process, creating inactive electrodes with cracks. And also, the shuttle effect which begins with the formation of polysulfides at the electrodes was the reason for the dissolution of those compounds in the electrolytes, creating a huge loss in electrode materials. This might end up in poor cyclic stability, auto discharging, and lower coulombic efficiency. Another issue with that is the insulating property of the S, Li2S, and Li2S2. Those two compounds are formed as the coating on the S molecules and stop further formations. Therefore, it is necessary to add conductive materials to improve electrochemical performances. However, all the above limitations can be overcome by modifying the cathode materials in LSBS. The last records reveal that various alternative materials such as metal-organic frameworks, graphene oxides, and metal oxides can be applied in place of S. But some of these materials are not exhibited good properties for electrodes. Considering that, MXenes have been discovered as the best option to improve the features of the cathode. This is because MXenes have unique morphological characteristics which contribute to developing the chemical contact S cathode with Li-based polysulfides (Li-PSs) and ion transportation among the electrodes [77]. To improve the slow kinetics of Li-S batteries and efficiently limit the shuttling impact of intermediate LiPSs, an ideal sulfur host must possess high electrical conductivity, great affinity to lithium polysulfides (LiPSs), and the capacity to accelerate sulfur redox. Due to its ability to fulfill the aforementioned criteria, MXenes has garnered considerable interest in the realm of Li-S batteries. Conductive framework in MXene-based sulfur hosts is often provided by MXenes. Using the HF etching process, Zhao et al. [80] first synthesised layered accordion-like Ti3C2 (L-Ti3C2) as a sulfur host. With a sulfur content of 57.6%, the S/L-Ti3C2 composite showed high capacity and outstanding cycle performance due to its accordion-like structure and low resistivity (0.05 m). In another work, Wang et al. [81] found that S-based MXene is a solution for the shuttle effect since S-functionalized V2C (V2CS2) shows moderate adsorption behavior [82]. When compared with the V2C, and V2CO2, this compound has a higher ability to maintain the structure without any changes after adsorbing Li-PSs. And also, V2CS2 needs low activation energy for getting the end product of Li2S and has a low energy obstacle to Li-ion transfer. This promotes better electrochemical performances during the CD process in Li-SBs. 4.2 MXene-based materials for supercapacitors The discovery of different types of electrode materials enhances the chemical performance of energy storage devices. Activated carbon, graphene, CPs, and metal oxides play an active role as effective electrode materials. Over the past decades, MXenes have become one of the fast-growing materials for SCs in energy systems. This is because of their attractive properties including rapid ion transfer within mono/multi-layered structures, high conductivity, excellent capacitance, etc. The capacitance of the MXenes varied based on the morphological features of the ions in the structures, the type of the electrolyte, and attached functional groups. Since Ti3C2Tx has low energy generation, it has become the first and most significant research finding among MXenes. Due to its unique characteristics, this has a great impact on the performance of SCs. Metal elements in Ti3C2Tx provide high density resulting in high volumetric capacitance. Also, its metal conductivity combined with hydrophilicity contributes to rapid ion transfer and electrolyte wetness. The most notable feature of Ti3C2Tx is its ability to change properties by modifying the attached functional groups (Tx). In particular, the surface can be negatively charged by substituting the -F, -O, -OH groups, and then this offers redox-active sites for reactions. Depending on the type of electrolytes, the capacitance properties of Ti3C2Tx can be changed. When Ti3C2Tx electrodes are in neutral organic or aqueous electrolytes, they behave as EDLCs. Therefore, it stores energy by forming a double layer between the electrode and electrolyte. When the charge is supplied, the ions in the electrolytes move to the layers of Ti3C2Tx with the electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged particles. In that sense, the small-sized electrolytic ion molecules can easily penetrate through the electrode layers while larger ones are adsorbed at the surface of the layers by forming the electrostatic repulsion in the layers. The smaller ions store charge by intercalation. Hence, it can maintain good stability within the system. Due to this adsorption process, a double layer is formed within interlayers to store charge. Based on that, the capacitance of Ti3C2Tx can be improved by enhancing the surface area, and size of the ions or decreasing the space between layers. [83]. Pseudocapacitive charge storage can be specified as a fast surface-limited redox reaction that reaches a high-rate capacitance. It can be observed that the electrode materials show pseudo-capacitance properties after modifying the surface with redox-active materials or electrolytes. As 2D materials, the pseudocapacitance of MXenes predominates in acidic aqueous electrolytes such as sulfuric acid [84]. Here, the small-sized hydrogen ions in sulfuric acid can easily transfer through the layers resulting in high conductivity. The intercalated ions formed a hydroxyl group by bonding with oxygen on the surface of Ti3C2Ox Eq. (18)) and the titanium was oxidized from +3 to +4. All the electrochemical reactions within this pseudo-capacitor can be noted briefly below Eqs. (18), and ((19). (18) T i 3 C 2 O x + δ e − + δ H + → T i 3 C 2 O x − δ ( OH ) δ (19) T i 3 C 2 O x − δ ( OH ) y F z + δ e − + δ K + → K δ T i 3 C 2 O x ( OH ) y F z From Eq. (18), it is noticeable fact that increasing the concentration of sulfuric acid leads to an improvement in the ion conductivity ending in a high specific capacitance of SCs. An equal outcome can be observed using alkaline electrolytes like KOH that produce ion intercalation without involving surface-active elements (Eq. (19)). Further, Li2SO4 aqueous solution containing neutral electrolyte ions has the potential to contribute to this process through the redox reactions, which take in the reversible insertion and removal of Li ions. Comparatively, the neutral aqueous electrolyte has the benefits of safer conditions in SCs. However, the energy density and the extension of working potential voltage are some limitations of this electrolyte. These issues can be overcome using ionic liquids (molten salts). Some research has shown that there is irreversible volume expansion of Ti3C2Tx in this electrolyte. Because of increased negativity of the surface and cation supply which affects the electro statistic equilibrium, volume widens a more negative potential window over the cycling process. This can also happen due to the elimination of ions and the contraction of electrostatic adsorption volume taking place with positive potential. Since non-aqueous electrolyte ions are small in size, they have a low effect of insertion, leading to low conductivity. This is the problem related to molten salt electrolytic behavior in SCs [83]. In the above sections, all the mechanisms behind each type of MXene-based SCs are clearly explained. When studying the past reports regarding the synthesis, most of the research was carried out using Ti-based MXenes composed with other materials. In particular, they found that the specific capacitance of MXenes can be improved by combining them with electrochemically active material rather than using these alone. For an instance, Rakhi et al. discovered a nanocomposite of MnO2/MXene as an electrode material for aqueous PCs which exhibits 210 F/g of specific capacitance and good electrochemical stability (88% of cap. retention over 10,000 charge-discharge cycles). Here, they selected Ti2CTx or Ti3C2Tx as MXenes for the fabrication of symmetric SCs and the ratio of MXene to MnO2 in the composite is 1:1. Further, the electrochemical features can be enhanced by removing TiO2 particles in the MXene sheets and by reducing the size of particles in MAX phase [85]. Further, another example of the synthesis of novel MXene-based SCs can be introduced with the invention of the WO3/Ti3C2 composite by Ambade and his group [86]. Two types of mono WO3 (crystalline monoclinic phase) and hexa WO3 (hollow tunnel in the hexagonal polymorph) were used in EESDs, especially in SCs. Herein, they used the hydrothermal electrostatic absorption technique for the production of mono WO3/ Ti3C2 and Hexa WO3/ Ti3C2. It is discovered that there is a difference in characteristics in both composites due to the changes in structures. It was confirmed that the Hexa composite illustrated higher specific capacitance (566 F/g) greater than the monotype. Those are involved in pseudocapacitive performances in SCs. Recently, most MXene-based SCs have been synthesized using titanium-based MXenes. However, more investigations related to MXene-based hybrid-ion capacitors and flexible SCs are discussed further in Sections 4.2.1 and 4.2.2. 4.2.1 Hybrid ion capacitors The hybrid capacitor is a sort of energy device that combines the benefits of supercapacitors and Li-ion batteries (LIBs) into a single system. The MXene hybrid capacitor is depicted in Fig. 12 a. One of the most well-known types of conventional hybrid capacitors is the lithium-ion capacitor (LIC). Flexible LIC devices that use MXenes are seeing increasing success. There have been a wide variety of electrode materials employed in LIC systems so far [87]. Due to the different Li-ion storage structures, the anode materials for LICs can be classified into three categories: insertion, conversion, and alloy. Graphite, hard carbon, titanium dioxide, lithium titanium tungstate (LTO), and niobium tungstate (Nb2O5) are all examples of insertion type materials. Unlike Li metal, insertion type materials have a lower theoretical capacity (400 mAh/g) or a higher voltage plateau, limiting their potential applications [88]. Second, the theoretical capacity of the alloy-type (Si, Sn, and Sn-based composites) and conversion-type (MoS2, MnO2, Fe3O4, CoO) materials is greater than that of the insertion-type material (>700 mAh/g). Electrode polarization and deterioration over cycling are exacerbated by the great irreversible strength, significant volume change, and sluggish kinetics of such materials [89]. The primary difficulties for the anode are the growth of electronic and ionic conductivity and the endurance of the ring. In this regard, materials with a well-designed or nano-sized design can effectively reduce the Li+ diffusion path and boost electron transport. Graphene, amorphous carbon, and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are the most popular cathode materials for LIC. Because of its high specific surface area, simple synthesis, lack of toxicity, and low price, AC has garnered a lot of attention among various materials. However, the low power density is a result of the low electron conductivity and the narrow pore size distribution of the material. Therefore, the adaptability and efficiency of LICs can be improved by using materials with a large surface area and an acceptable pore size distribution [90]. To achieve high-performance electrochemical energy recovery, the LIC, as a full-cell hybrid electrochemical capacitor, necessitates a large-capacity Li+ reversible intercalation anode. MXenes have a special, extremely thin, fully accessible layer structure that makes Li+ intercalation/deintercalation kinetics easier. So, MXenes don't make the best batteries, but the fact that they are close to a capacitor suggests they could be used in LICs [91]. Furthermore, the functional groups (O, Cl, F, and OH) on the surface of MXene layers have a substantial impact on the qualities of energy recovery, MXene stability, and electronic transmission speed. Various MXene electrodes were synthesized using various methods and etchant to achieve a high-capacity electrode for hybrid LIC application. When compared to single MXene materials, composite flexible materials (Ti3C2Tx @Fe2O3 and CTAB-Sn(IV)@Ti3C2) exhibited excellent specific capacities. When measured anodically at 10 mV/s and 250 mAh/g, the energy density of Ti3C2Tx and Ti2CTx electrodes was approximately 20.7 Wh/cm2 and 160 Whk/g, respectively. The maximum anodic capacities of 1180 mAh/g @ 0.1A/g and 675 mAh/g @ 0.1A/g for the composite MXene Ti3C2Tx@Fe2O3 and CTAB-Sn(IV)@Ti3C2 electrodes, respectively, contribute to the composite system's high energy density value of 216 Whk/g and 105.6 Wh/kg ( Fig. 12 (b-e)) [90]. 4.2.2 Flexible supercapacitors The innovations of wearable apparatus and sensors with stretching properties have promoted the modification of electrode materials in the power sources like SCs and batteries. As discussed earlier, SCs are considered a promising candidate for the fabrication of wearable devices, due to their higher cycle stability, power density, and specific capacitance compared with batteries. Currently, novel 2D material MXenes are designed to be the best alternator instead of low dimensional nanomaterials (graphene, carbon nanotubes). Because MXenes have unique properties which can be applied to the production of both flexible and rigid EESDs. Their conductance is more than 10,000 S/m similar to metals and the volumetric capacitance is up to 1500 F/cm3. Moreover, the hydrophilic groups in MXenes provide a stable dispersion in aqueous solutions. But it is a challenge to produce stretchable MXene-based SCs, because of their weak interlayer interaction and high mechanical stiffness. This is because there are fewer records regarding the stretchable MXene-based EESDs [93]. However, to achieve higher flexibility and wearable compatibility the pure MXenes are mixed with CPs (polypyrrole-PPy, polyaniline-PANI, polythiophene-PTh) and its derivatives such as poly (3,4-ethylene dioxythiophene)-[PEDOT], etc. When only pure MXenes are used for the electrodes instead of composites, this would break into small pieces under the same conditions and better performance cannot be obtained using MXene alone. Not only that, this is a protection mechanism of the structure from shrinkage and swelling during charge-discharge processes [94]. Zhou et al. [93] discovered another route for the fabrication of stretchable SCs using the composite of Ti3C2Tx-reduced graphene oxide (RGO). this structure has larger RGO flakes in size which provide a strong interaction between layers with the increase of the connection areas. The small-sized MXene support to transport ions results in good conductivity. Due to the presence of hydroxyl and carboxyl groups on the layers, RGO flakes have high surface energy. This may improve the strength of the interlayer interactions between RGO-MXene and among RGO flakes. These features directly affect flexibility and toughness improvements in Ti3C2Tx/RGO-based devices. The prepared Ti3C2Tx/RGO composite conductors remain the highest stretchability with chemical conductance after extreme stretching at 300% uniaxially (1D) and 200% −200% biaxially (2D). Further, the SCs made with these materials showed 18.6 mF/cm2 of specific capacitance, 90 F/cm3 of volumetric capacitance, and 29 F/g of gravimetric capacitance. For the fabrication of flexible asymmetric SCs, MXene (Ti3C2Tx) with carbon black (CB) electrodes in gel polymer (Li2SO4 -PVA)electrolyte was used by Chang and his crew [95]. Lately, hair-like CNTs or long polymeric chains are combined with MXenes to increase stretchiness. However, these devices maintained high electrochemical performances at 100% 1D stretchability and 180° bendability under stress conditions ( Fig. 13 ). This exhibited high cyclic stability after 3000 cycles even at tensile strains in the range of 80–100%. Here, they used the in-situ HF method for the synthesis of Ti3C2Tx. Further, this was hybridized with a polymer binder, sodium alginate (SA). These polymer chains have oxygen-containing functional groups that attach to the MXene by forming a hydrogen bond. Due to this bond, the retention of conductivity and the mechanical stability of MXenes nano-coatings were increased. The drawbacks of this were the time-consuming and complexity of the procedure. Tong et al. [94] used the different compositions of composite (PPy/Ti3C2Tx) for the synthesis of symmetric solid-state SCs which have the features of flexibility, and high capacitance. Here, etching, vacuum-assisted filtration method, and then electrochemical deposition of PPy on the layer were applied for obtaining these composite layers. Due to the rough surface, this composite has a high surface area allowing more sites to store energy. Therefore, this electrode material exhibits 420.2 F/g of specific capacitance with better stability at about 86% cap. retention over 10,000 CD cycles. In that case, stretchable SC was fabricated using those two symmetric electrodes in PVA/ H2SO4 gel electrolyte. By analyzing data, they have recognized that the composite was rich with properties of both SCs resulting from Ti3C2Tx performed double-layer capacitance while PPy showed pseudocapacitive activity. As the latest innovation, in 2022, Li. Chenglong et al. [96] found a new route for the synthesis of sandwich-like flexible, symmetric SC using MXene, and α-Fe2O3-C-MoS2-PEDOT: PSS (FMP) as electrodes. By adding FMP into Ti3C2Tx (M), the capacitance area was significantly increased. When considering the FMP composite, α-Fe2O3 is popular in SCs due to its properties of wide working voltage, redox activity, inexpensive, eco-friendliness, and higher availability. Particularly, both α-Fe2O3 and MoS2 were used for electrodes combined with conductive materials such as CNT, graphene, or other TMOs. Because of the poor conductivity of PSS, it was mixed with PEDOT which is considered a conductive polymer. Thus, this research group discovered that a combination of all those materials in proportion gives better electrochemical performances. Here, they made SCs as M/FMP/M on carbon cloth in PVA/ H2SO4 gel electrolyte ( Fig. 14 ). This exhibits a high specific capacitance of 541 F/g at a scan rate of 3 mV/s which was a higher value compared with other reported MXene-based SCs. This motivates the large-scale production of flexible and portable devices using this composition of electrodes. 5 Conclusion and remarks 5.1 Summary With the development of the composition, morphology of the electrode materials, fabrication techniques, and characterization methods, the electrochemical performance of the devices has changed. As mentioned earlier, recently, MXene is becoming an effective electrode material for the production of batteries and supercapacitors. These have become great innovations in the field of sustainable energy. Records have proven that this material has a vast future in the application of energy devices because of its unique characteristics. Herein, the overview of synthesis methods, properties, and electrochemical charge storage applications in batteries and supercapacitors are discussed in detail in Sections 2-4 respectively. By summarizing all the above details of each MXene-based energy storage device, MXene SCs show both pseudocapacitive and electric double-layer mechanisms. Considering the factors of eco-friendliness, availability, cost-effectiveness, and high capacitance, Ti-based MXenes (Ti2CTx and Ti3C2Tx) are more popular among SCs and metal-ion batteries. They exhibit high density resulting in excellent volumetric capacity. The electrochemical activity of MXenes can be improved by composition with other metal oxides. Like SCs, MXene-type batteries are also popular among EESDs due to their unique features of high energy density and longer life cycles. In the case of metal-ion batteries, MXenes act as anode and cathode in LIBs and LSBs respectively. LIBs showed high performance compared with others. Nevertheless, LSBs have some limitations which hamper their electrochemical activity. Therefore, it is necessary to modify the MXene by composing it with conductive material to improve the properties of LSBs. Thus, still, some shortcomings cannot be solved. This is because some of LSB's findings are limited to research, not to commercial outcomes. Some MXene-based flexible SCs have invaded the textile field in large-scale productions. But the required stretching level cannot be reached using MXenes alone. So, conductive polymers are mixed with them in the production of stretchable MXene electrodes. It is noticeable that most of the research was carried out related to Ti-based MXenes. Thus, this field of research can be expanded through the investigations of other elements, overcoming deficiencies not only for energy storage but also for various purposes. 5.2 Challenges and future prospective Modifying the surface chemistry of MXenes makes it possible to improve their electrical, mechanical, and electrochemical charge storage properties, and therefore these materials are highly amenable to being explored in batteries and supercapacitors. MXene-based electrodes with the aforesaid features validated them as prospective electrode materials of choice with the constraint of stability, and therefore, further investigation should be conducted to achieve the desirable development of the energy storage sector. Functionalized MXene with -F and -O terminations showed increased electrochemical charge storage performance, although precise performance measurements may be challenging without a tunable surface termination. Due to strong bonding between atomic components in the MAX phase, the exfoliation of multi-layers is not possible via conventional etching methods, requiring a strong etchant like HF, which invites unwanted environmental issues. Moreover, strong interaction between MAX phase layers raises the question of how a high charge storage capacity may be attained after a very mild but steady operation with the etchant. Therefore, numerous methods should be explored to improve their charge storage performances, including altering the boundary state, functional groups, and defect state, making use of confinement effects, and manufacturing the heterostructures. Even though combining MXene with other promising materials made it better at storing charge, these studies are still in their early stages and required more investigations in the future to develop ideal materials for electrochemical energy storage application. In addition to providing a good substrate for the ionic intercalation, a promising feature of hybrid ionic capacitors, the promotion effect of MXene on their charge storage capacity should be fully investigated using theoretical calculations and modeling. Moreover, functionalized MXenes are being looked at as the next generation of flexible materials for batteries and supercapacitors. For better ideas about future uses in this direction, it is required to know more about how the surface species of pure MXene bond with each other. Furthermore, MXene's instability is a significant barrier to its synthesis and practical application, with temperature and humidity being the two most crucial factors in MXene oxidation. However, MXene with several layers offers outstanding oxidation resistance. The edges are the key regions on the surface of MXenes where oxidation occurs quickly; therefore, by shielding them, excessive oxidation of MXenes can be minimized. Furthermore, cations adhering to the edges with adequate control and antioxidant properties may improve MXene dispersion. The key approaches that indicated how to regulate MXene oxidation were lowering the temperature, reducing oxygen, and drying the sample. Further theoretical and experimental research is needed to gain a thorough knowledge of structural and functional relationships with stability and electrochemical performance. The pricey nature of the precursors used in MXene production is another drawback. The expensive procedures used to synthesize MXene completely negate any commercial viability the material might otherwise have. These problems need to be fixed by finding inexpensive precursors. Substantial research is required to find a low-cost method of producing MXene. Consequently, overall costs can be reduced, making their industrial applications feasible. Moreover, the structure and compositional evolution of MXene electrodes may be better understood with the help of state-of-the-art characterization methods such as in-situ analysis, synchrotron radiation systems, and solid-state nuclear magnetic techniques. This will help in the investigation of the crucial relationships between structure, property, and performance, as well as in the screening of various MXene and MAX phases. coredata.dc:description: For the past two decades starting from 2004, 2D dimensional materials-based research has begun around single-layer graphene materials. As a result of a long-term effort, this interest was turned in another direction with the discovery of MXene materials in 2011. Later, this attracted tremendous attention as an excellent electrode material for the fabrication of energy storage devices due to its uncommon features of hydrophilicity and conductivity. Since it owned both pseudo-capacitive and electric double-layer behaviors, it is in high demand for the production of supercapacitors. Their inherent characteristics also lead to the promotion of electrochemical performance in batteries such as metal-ion, metal sulfur, etc. These types of apparatus were invented as a result of MXene's unique features of surface reactivity, higher density, kinetically sensitive structures, etc. Due to these advanced properties, this material is widely used in electric vehicles, sensors, catalysis, electronic devices, etc. Herein, some basic aspects of variations in MXenes, their synthesis methods, their contribution to energy storage, and their applications are discussed throughout this review article. The main focus of this review is on the energy storage mechanism of different types of MXene-based devices. It is further intended to illustrate that the flexible MXene-derived devices are also beneficial in various applications like wearable, sensing, etc.
coredata.dc:title: MXene-based promising nanomaterials for electrochemical energy storage
